quote: For this child I prayed, and the Lord has granted.
firstReading: Hannah, having borne the son she prayed for, brings the boy Samuel to the sanctuary at Shiloh. There she presents him to Eli, offers a sacrifice to the LORD, and formally dedicates the child to God’s service. Hannah leaves Samuel to live and minister at the house of the LORD, entrusting him to Eli’s care. The passage highlights a vow fulfilled and a mother’s sacrificial handing over of a beloved child to God’s call.
psalmSummary: Hannah’s song (1 Samuel 2:1, 4-5, 6-7, 8abcd) exults in God’s overturning of human expectations: she praises God who raises the lowly, casts down the proud, and satisfies the hungry. The psalm declares Yahweh’s sovereign power over life and death, poverty and riches, and portrays God as protector of the faithful. Its confident, even polemical, tone celebrates divine justice and mercy enacted in history.
gospelSummary: In the Magnificat (Luke 1:46-56) Mary responds to Elizabeth with a hymn of praise that magnifies God’s mercy. She extols God’s saving deeds: remembering the lowly, scattering the proud, bringing down rulers, and lifting up the humble. The song frames God’s action as fulfillment of promise to Israel, overturning worldly hierarchies and feeding the hungry while sending the rich away empty. Mary’s joy is rooted in God’s faithfulness and compassion, and her witness inaugurates the inbreaking of God’s kingdom through Christ.
saintReflection: Feria of Late Advent: December 22 is a late‑Advent weekday without an obligatory saint in the General Roman Calendar; the liturgy is dominated by the O Antiphons and the Gospel of the Visitation and Magnificat.[193][219] The Church’s prayer focuses on Mary’s praise of God’s mercy and on the imminent birth of Christ, inviting deeper interior preparation rather than attention to particular saints.
dailyPrayer: O God of mercy, you hear the cry of your people and lift up the lowly. As Hannah entrusted Samuel to your house and Mary entrusted herself to your word, grant that we may offer our lives in service and praise. Give us the humility to be shaped by your purposes, the courage to surrender what we cherish for the sake of your kingdom, and eyes to see your providential action in the lowly and the overlooked. Prepare our hearts to welcome Christ with gratitude, obedience, and joy. Through Jesus Christ, who comes in mercy. Amen.
theologicalSynthesis: The readings for this late Advent weekday present a tightly knit theological theme: God’s faithful reversal of human situations and the proper human response of surrender and praise. Hannah’s dedication of Samuel is matched by Mary’s Magnificat: both stories center on women who receive God’s favor and respond by offering their children or themselves to God’s salvific plan. The psalm underscores divine sovereignty—life and death, poverty and riches lie in God’s hand—while the Gospel frames God’s action as mercy that fulfills promises to Israel. The liturgy summons believers to interior preparation: to trust, to humble service, and to praise that witnesses God’s saving work now and in the coming Christ.
exegesis:
Context: The passage from 1 Samuel sits at a turning point in Israel’s history. Hannah’s long infertility and vow culminate in a child dedicated to God’s service, a story that introduces Samuel’s prophetic and judicial role. The narrative contrasts personal piety and institutional religion: Hannah’s private suffering becomes public praise when she fulfills her vow in the sanctuary. The scene anticipates the establishment of prophetic leadership and points to how God raises leaders from unlikely places. The account also exemplifies a biblical pattern in which God answers prayer and repurposes human joy for communal service.

Psalm: The song attributed to Hannah (1 Samuel 2) is one of the Old Testament’s earliest canticles and serves as a theological commentary on the events. Its language celebrates a God who disrupts social hierarchies—raising the lowly, bringing down the mighty, turning the fortunes of the poor and hungry. This motif of reversal is not merely social critique but an affirmation that Yahweh’s covenant faithfulness overturns human pride and secures justice. The psalm’s theological weight lies in portraying God as ultimate arbiter of life, who gives and takes, elevates and humbles according to divine wisdom.

Gospel: Luke’s Magnificat (Luke 1:46-56) echoes Hannah’s song and transposes its themes into the new-covenant context of Mary’s consent. Mary’s hymn frames God’s action in terms of mercy and promise-keeping: the fulfillment of God’s purpose for Israel is characterized by the reversal of worldly values—pride is scattered, the humble are exalted, the hungry are filled. Luke intentionally links these two female voices to show continuity between Israel’s story and the inbreaking reign of God in Christ. Mary’s Magnificat also functions as early Christian theology: God’s salvation is not impersonal law but merciful, concrete action that transforms social relations.

Saints: The liturgical choice to keep December 22 as a feria of late Advent focuses the Church’s gaze on these scriptural women rather than on additional commemorations. Both Hannah and Mary become models of faith—women who experience deep longing, receive God’s intervention, and consecrate what they have been given. The absence of a named saint directs attention to communal prayer and to the O Antiphons and Magnificat that shape the last octave of Advent. The liturgy thereby invites the faithful to emulate the virtues displayed: patient hope, wholehearted surrender, and praise that recognizes God’s mercy.

Today: For contemporary believers the readings call for an interior posture of readiness and conversion. Advent’s final days are less about external preparation and more about the disposition with which we receive Christ. Hannah’s act of dedication challenges us to consider what we are willing to entrust to God—our time, resources, relationships. Mary’s Magnificat invites us to a theology of the poor: to see God’s work where the world sees weakness. Practically, this means aligning our priorities with mercy, advocating for those whom society overlooks, and allowing liturgical prayer to reshape our imaginations about power and success.

Conclusion: The combined witness of Hannah, the psalmist, and Mary forms a coherent Advent catechesis: God acts decisively for the poor and lowly, and the human response is humble trust and praise. As the Church waits, the challenge is to let the Magnificat and Hannah’s dedication form our hearts—so that when Christ comes, we greet him not merely with external preparations but with lives already conformed to his mercy and justice.
